section.title: Minimum CPU architecture support
section.para: 1 To improve overall performance, &slsa; 16 also delivers some shared libraries optimized for x86-64-v3. These libraries will be installed and used automatically on systems supporting v3. You can tell a package was optimized if its name includes the string x86_42_v3.
2 &slsa; 16 removes 32-bit application support. The Linux kernel can still enable 32-bit system calls by installing the grub2-compat-ia32 package from the &ph;.
3 &slsa; 16 can be run on Power9 but &suse; supports only Power10 and above.

listitem.para: &slea; 15 uses Service Packs (SPs) for annual updates, such as SP1, SP2, SP3, SP4, SP5, SP6, and SP7, which is the last SP released for &slea; 15.

SLE 16 introduces a new naming schema for versions, using minor releases like 16.0, 16.1, instead of SPs. Releases are scheduled annually and always in November. The initial release, 16.0, is planned for November 2025.

&sls; 15 has general support for 1.5 years per Service Pack (with exceptions) and offers various extended support options like LTSS (Long Term Service Pack Support) and ESPOS (Extended Service Pack Overlap Support). Total support for SLE 15 covers up to 13 years (10 years general support + 3 years LTSS). &slsa; 15 SP7 general support is until 2031-07-31, with LTSS until 2034-07-31 and LTSS Core until 2037-12-31. &sles4sap; 15 SPs has a total support period of 4.5 years.

&slsa; 16 is ready for the future beyond 2038. General Support is expected to end in November 2035, with LTSS and Extreme LTSS beyond 2040. &sles4sap; 16 has general support for 1.5 years plus 3 years extended support.
In &slea; 15 and earlier, &yast; was used for installation, configuration and systems management. Unattended and scripted installation was performed by &ay;.
In &slea; 16, systems management sees significant changes:

Installation (including unattended) transitions to &agama;. &agama; is a new installer with a Web-based front-end, command-line interface, and API for integration. It focuses on the installation in favor of software configuration management (SCM) tools. Agama supports repeated configuration import.
Configuration management uses &salt; and &ansible; via &smlm;. This supports customers with ready-to-run automation.
Remote management is handled by &cockpit;, a Web-based front-end for 1:1 management.

These changes in &slea; 16 aim to provide better integration with &salt; and &ansible;, allow remote installation via a Web browser, and offer different interfaces (Web, CLI, HTTP API) for controlling the process.
&slea; 15 uses &aa; by default. &selnx; is shipped without policies.

&slea; 16 ships &selnx; with policies for over 400 modules by default, confining almost the whole system. Parts of the system can run unconfined if desired. &sles4sap; 16 has improved workload isolation with &selnx;, providing isolation for data and data flows, and for containers.
&slea; 15 used wicked and &nm;.
&slea; 16 focuses on a single stack using &nm;.

&slea; 15 offered ready-to-run images for virtual machines or public clouds and installation media for manual deployment with &yast; or automated with &ay;. It used a special installation environment with linuxrc-driven configuration. &ay; profile import was a one-off task only.

&slea; 16 uses ready-to-run images for virtual machines or public clouds, and manual/automated deployment with &agama;. The &agama; installer is accessible via a Web interface, command line or HTTP API. &agama; allows repeated configuration import. It uses a standard live medium with dracut, &systemd;, and NetworkManager and provides a backward-compatibility layer with selected linuxrc options.
&slea; 15 used &systemd; with native units and compatibility for 3rd party SysV init scripts.
&slea; 16 completes the transition from SysV init and uses &systemd; native units exclusively.
In &slea; 15, the default OS configuration was primarily in /etc.

In &slea; 16, defaults are in /usr and /etc is for customization. This separation of vendor-provided defaults and administrator customization allows easier updates and — optionally — read-only /usr file system.
In &slea; 15 /tmp was a regular folder or partition. In the default configuration with Btrfs as root file system, it was a Btrfs subvolume.
In &slea; 16, /tmp uses the tmpfs file system, which stores data in physical RAM and/or swap space, making it very fast for read and write operations.

important.title: /tmpis no longer persistent
important.para: On tmpfs, the content of /tmp is not persistent between reboots. If you have applications that write persistent data to /tmp, adopt them to use a different location such as /var/cache.

important.title: Do not oversize /tmp
important.para: Oversizing tmpfs file system instances beyond the the sum of physical RAM and swap space of a system can lead to deadlock situations where the system becomes unresponsive due to insufficient available memory.

listitem.para: &slea; 15 used &gnome; as the default desktop environment. &sled; and &slewe; shared desktop productivity tools.
&slea; 16 uses a minimal &gnome; desktop. This helps minimize the security surface. &sled; is not planned for 16.0.

entry.para: All agents in a single package

section.title: Removed technology
section.para: &slea; 16 removes certain technologies to reduce the OS footprint and the security attack vector:

listitem.para: System: 32-bit application support is removed. The Linux kernel can still enable 32-bit system calls by installing the grub2-compat-ia32 package from the &ph;.
System: SysV init scripts are removed; use native &systemd; units instead.
Network: wicked is removed in favor of &nm;.
Network: NIS is no longer used; choose LDAP instead.
Network: The ISC DHCP server was removed in favor of the more modern Kea DHCP.
Virtualization: The &xen; hypervisor was removed in favor of &kvm;. You can still run &slea; 16 as &xen; guest, but not as &xen; host.
Windows Subsystem for Linux: Support for WSL1 was removed in favor of WSL2, offering a full Linux kernel with complete system call compatibility.
